text: before we get into today's podcast I
wanted to share that Yukon London
returns April 7 to 9
2025 learn what's next from worldclass
leaders pushing the boundaries you'll
learn actionable insights from senior
software developers working on real
world projects across multiple domains
learn more at qconlondon.com
[Music]
good day folks this is Shane Hasty for
the InfoQ Engineering Culture Podcast
today I'm sitting down with Sega Bachu
from Speak Easy sega welcome thanks for
taking the time to talk to us today
thank you Shane uh really excited to be
here i've been a long-term follower of
InfoQ so this is a really exciting
moment for me thank you and we
appreciate you following us so my normal
starting point on these conversations is
who is Sega
well maybe I'll start in reverse i'm
coming to you today as a CEO co-founder
of Speak Easy we're a pretty young
startup here based out of the Bay Area
and London we're a what we call a
developer tools company so we build a
tool chain that helps developers
everywhere build great APIs and I kind
of start here because the last two and a
half years or so as you might expect
this has kind of completely taken over
my life in a good way i love working on
it and so these days I spend my time
building and growing this company we're
a small company of 20some people we have
a growing customer base we have some
early passion employees all around the
globe and so yeah that's where I'm
coming to you from and the journey I've
gotten to here is kind of an interesting
one i actually didn't start in software
my background is in physics that's what
I studied and so how my journey evolved
is I was actually thinking about doing
experimental physics i was going down
the path of doing a PhD and I realized
at the time what I loved more than
anything was actually building the
software to do the data analysis and you
know actually constructing all of that
tech around the experimental physics and
so instead of getting a PhD I kind of
pivoted into software entered the
indicator in kind of early 2010s
actually a really great time i was very
lucky to come to the Bay Area at that
time and work in various startups and
over that time I got lots of exposure to
big data APIs it was kind of the early
cloud era as well i worked for an adtech
company called Live Ramp that was a
massive scale company in terms of data
and APIs and we did this massive cloud
migration from onrem to Google Cloud i
think we were like the second largest
customer behind Spotify for a long time
so it was a really exciting journey and
through that it was probably one of my
most foundational experiences as a
person and as a kind of employee and it
also took me out to London and I got
this amazing opportunity to kind of grow
and build an engineing team based out
there and really helped define a kind of
fledgling part of the business and yeah
all of that together I think has led me
back to the Bay Area today and where I'm
lucky to be working on this kind of
developer tools kind of just kind of
culmination of all of the various things
that I've been able to do over the last
kind of decade or in the industry so
let's dig into a few of these points but
one I'd like to dig into is moving from
the Bay Area to London and starting up a
new venture there what was interesting
or difficult or exciting about that so I
think what was really interesting about
that journey was I entered it thinking
hey I'm already working for a big
company um they're starting a new team
like hey let's put my hand up it's going
to be a fun journey to go out there and
kind of take my learnings and continue
to be an IC and once I did I realized
actually it was going out to help build
out a completely different part of the
business that actually was essentially a
startup all we had was an MD a few early
salespeople basically no tech team yet
and really kind of vision but not much
execution yet so I had never done
anything like that like it was a
shocking expense to go out there and be
handed like an empty slate right right
and as an engineer many of us as we
start our careers we usually enter teams
systems and software that have already
established patterns have you know
established pans for development but
also established patterns for growth and
how the teams are structured and all of
that and so it was definitely a really
crazy way to be pushed as an IC to be
put in that position so it ended up
becoming actually five years of working
closely with the business team to help
define a new market um we were at tech
so building in Europe doing GDPR's roll
out was actually a really fascinating
experience of how to navigate software
and regulation at the same time then
also kind of building the team and
learning how to hire in a new market
where you have no contacts you realize
that actually engineers don't want to be
reached out to directly they like
agencies and they like recruiters all
those kind of learnings and so it was
honestly a new experience for me all the
way from the tech to the people to kind
of business building and what it means
to be more than just an engineer right
to be a kind of engineering manager
engineering leader eventually director
and a VP and you get thrown at the
frying pan and you figure it out i think
that's really what that experience was
for me so you've gone through the
journey from individual contributor all
the way through now to founder the steps
on that journey one of the first steps
and I think one that a lot of our
audience is going to be looking at is
that shift from individual contributor
to a team lead to lead engineer and
stereotypically what we do is we take
the best engineer and we throw them into
this new role and we give them no
support and training and we hope that
they can figure it out what's your
experience been and how can we do it
better yeah big question Shane so I
think you're absolutely right
prototypically on a team you take the
best developer and then you make them a
manager and I actually think
unfortunately that's not a complete
criteria to find the best manager
sometimes on a team and so I think the
first and foremost thing that probably
we should do as an industry is and I
think it's happened over the years is
understand that going from being an IC
to a leader on a team or manager is a
very different set of expectations and
very different definition of success or
like what does great look like right and
so I think the promotion process
especially for companies that are well
established should really talk through
the differences in growing as an IC and
differences in growing as an injuring
leader i think those are two different
things and it's not saying you know I
think people think implicitly it means
one's less technical than the other i
don't think that's necessarily true i
think especially in today's kind of
ecosystem and great engineing leader can
still be very technical but the
definition of success and and what it
means for them to be successful is very
different i think in my experience what
I found was like as you become an engine
leader you get closer and closer to
owning revenue as any leader does in the
business right you are owning some
component of revenue whether it's
bringing new business promoting the
success of existing business or growing
a talent pool of people that will help
bring more business in later so it's
kind of always goes back to that and so
for me as an injuring manager and that
to in a new market it was really doing
whatever it took to help the business
team get traction and bring new users
and new customers in i think for a lot
of injuring managers it can be a little
bit more aligned towards an established
product and so that can mean really
defining and finding the right KPI for
their team is probably one of the most
important things a manager leader can do
and so I would say that's kind of the
first thing I would really push people
to think about is in that growth path
from IC to manager making sure that
you're aware of what is great look like
and how is it different than being let's
say you know going from an L5 to an L6
versus kind of stepping sideways in
going to an EM or some other kind of
leadership role so that'd be kind of
where I would start and what are the
pitfalls what are the risks in that
journey pitfalls or risks in the journey
is I think as developers we have a
certain intuition that we fall back to
like a technical intuition that is
basically very close to the product
right it's all about what is the best
way to build something or what is the
best way to design like at the end of
the day we're very much creators and
builders right like we like to put
together different components and we
really think about things bottoms up
right we think about how do we construct
a system a classic systems thinker is
someone who looks at all the components
and decides like how do you stack them
together I think sometimes as a leader
you have to have that perspective but
the often pitfall is that you don't have
the perspective from the other side
right which is you know instead of
looking bottoms up can you look tops
down and say what are the top one two or
three things that are important for a
business to achieve and let's go from
there I think that's one of the pitfalls
for any leader and I think it happens
especially on engineering leaders who
have started as IC's which is almost all
of us and so I think that's the main
pitfall that I have also fallen into is
like kind of thinking two systems
forward rather than making sure you have
really clear grasp of what are the
business goals the KPI and then working
up top down from there and then really
delegating to other leaders that you
have either with you or under you to
make those granular decisions part of
leadership in organizations is owning
culture what is culture and what is good
culture yeah great question you know
early in my career I used to think a lot
about what it means to be ex Google or
ex Facebook or ex Uber right these kind
of little phrases we had to describe
people who had worked at certain
companies was quite common amongst me
and my friends and I realized that the
reason that they said it was it was kind
of an indication of culture or technical
experience a bit of a broadstrokes way
of categorizing people into these
buckets and so I think that was
something I've always thought about with
culture is that sometimes the best way
to understand culture is actually once
you leave an organization right and you
leave it and you realize what are the
kind of main things that you're taking
away and what do other people see in you
when you go to a new organization that's
probably a reflection of culture that
you had in the kind of the last
experience so something I say on my team
today is the kind of culture I want to
build at the company is one where when
people leave and go to onto the next
opportunity one day being able to say
they worked at speak easy will have some
kind of gravity or weight for themselves
as a foundational experience but also
the kind of people they go work with so
I think the culture is really those set
of experiences that ends up making it a
foundational experience for you is there
anything at all in experience that you
would take away i think that really is
culture you know I think another popular
thing everyone knows is people join
companies but they lead managers and I
think that's a reflection of culture as
well right is at the end of the day the
culture ends up becoming the kind of
binding glue that helps you go through
the up and down and build some
resilience so I think there's a lot to
it there those are some things that
stand out to me as a leader how do you
frame and build that culture i've always
been one that cares a lot about autonomy
and really driving kind of high
ownership i think the first big
realization for me on culture is being
okay to let people kind of create the
culture organically which means people
will misstep there will be things that
you don't agree with there will be kind
of moments where you don't feel like
it's how you would do things but you
have to kind of let it play out and let
the culture kind of form organically and
really where you can steer and guide as
a leader I think is really thinking
through some of the kind of core tenants
around which the company can revolve
like you know one that we really talk
about especially as a very product heavy
team is asking for forgiveness and not
permission right as a high autonomy
company being okay with individuals
making decisions and with conv fiction
going through as long as they own the
consequences and kind of implications
then we should be comfortable with
people making those decisions in the
areas that they own and so that's kind
of an example of one of those central
tenants around which you can revolve as
a company i think those are the ways you
can steer but outside of that I think I
do let the team and the company kind of
make its decisions and both I think make
mistakes you know have wins have losses
and I think at a at a meta level as a
leader you have to kind of be okay with
those ups and downs for the culture to
really solidify otherwise the culture is
really kind of a house of cards that
you're holding up right and every
interaction needs you to kind of be you
know a good interaction that's not
sustainable and ultimately that's not
culture right that means it's just you
rather than some kind of culture that
permeates past you high autonomy
allowing people to make decisions and to
own the results of those how does that
play out high autonomy can lead to a few
things i think the positives are that
you will probably have happier employees
people who feel empowered they're making
decisions they get to make big decisions
small decisions live with both up and
down and they will probably learn faster
as a result i think a another real
positive autonomy is it reduces the
stress on managers and leaders to kind
of be the gatekeepers of decision-
making i think the not so positive part
of autonomy that you have to live with
is the chaos it can be more chaotic
there's more you know kind of movement
at all levels of the organization and so
there's often a little bit it's a little
bit more messy on the margins there's
more chaos in the decision- making and
so I think the highly autonomous
behavior works great for early companies
at our stage right where what you really
care about is that employee passion the
speed the velocity at which you can move
as a company i think companies at our
stage velocity is our only friend that's
the only thing that's kind of you know
pushing the company forward so I think
that's it worked really well at us as
you get bigger I think the autonomy has
to be traded off with kind of a little
bit more consistency i think it my last
company live ramp I saw that as we got
bigger a lot of the engineering
initiatives went from being kind of
driven off autonomy and about product
building to more about creating a
consistent experience yeah so I think
autonomy can go both ways but I think at
an early stage company I'm a big
proponent of it how do you keep the
blast radius small
yeah it's a good question i think to
keep the blast radius small autonomy
pairs really well with ownership and
kind of well-defined ownership you know
something we did recently as a company
was for the first time in the company's
short history evolved from having one
engineering team to multiple engineering
teams and a big question was what is
each engineering team going to own if
every team's going to be autonomous and
make decisions then the ownership has to
be really clear otherwise there will be
kind of chaos and an unnecessary chaos
that we are taking on ourselves so I
think autonomy can work really well when
the ownership is clear in in our case we
decided to go down the path of product
teams or revenue teams where every team
owns kind of full stack development all
the way from the sale of the product to
how it's built and deployment front to
back and so the ownership is really
clear as far as what each team owns and
now we can kind of let each team operate
and own an end to-end life cycle of both
the product sales support and all of
that so I think that's one way to reduce
the blast radius for a highly autonomous
organization is making sure the
decisions fall within a kind of clear
bound of ownership what are the other
challenges that you've dealt with in
this growth path i think growing from a
senior IC into an EM has been
challenging i think I did it in a
non-traditional way where I was forced
into it as a result of kind of location
shift to a new market as opposed to more
traditional you kind of get mentored by
engineing manager and you grow that way
it was a tough learning experience to
kind of be thrown into that position i
think the second big one has been really
taking the leap from an engineering
leader of any kind into a founder which
honestly is the kind of leap of faith
that you really just have to close your
eyes and take a jump and hope that it
works out there's kind of no amount of
preparation anyone can give you mentally
for the kind of shift in role it's going
to be so I think the thing that stands
out the most to me as a founder is that
it's very hard to find people with
empathy for the position you're in and
so I find that actually on a week-to-eek
basis I kind of seek out conversations
with other founders because even if
they're in completely different
industries like e-commerce or finance or
something else the kind of journey of a
founder the amount of like up and down
and emotional swinging it gives you can
only be empathized through talking to
someone else who is going through that
or has gone through it so I think that's
been a very tough learning growth
experience for me is realizing that the
founding journey is actually one where
very few people can actually empathize
with some of the problems you're facing
and shifting focus from the people stuff
to the technology you're an API company
what's the implication of all of these
AI agents on APIs today it's really
fascinating time to watch the technology
emerge it's so fun to play with and kind
of look at kind of like taking a peek
into the future of development that's no
longer purely human driven or at least
predominantly human driven to
development that is primarily machine
driven is really a crazy thing to think
about like I just think about it our
flow as developers every day everything
from writing code to version control to
shipping code to deployment it's all
designed to solve problems for humans
right the whole concept of developer
experience is all about humans even
things like authentication is all about
humans right you know you have to log
into a portal and get a key or get an OT
token or something like that it's all
about how people interact with systems
and so with agents kind of have this
paradigm shift that if we are to go into
a place where agents you know
essentially little applications make the
calls on behalf of humans and even write
the code on behalf of humans you kind of
realize you know after you watch the
demos and the excitement kind of
subsidize you realize that every piece
of tech we have today is not really
optimized for that like even the agents
that we're seeing today that can make
API calls on our behalf they are really
working within the framework or kind of
scaffolding of all the software that's
been designed for humans and I'll give
you a really concrete example like when
you think about APIs API authentication
is a really big problem around which
there are many big businesses that are
being built when I think through that I
think about something like OOTH
authentication which is all about
authentication for APIs creating scopes
making sure that you know the right APIs
can be accessed by the right actors and
those oath workflows all about humans
you know taking their usernames and
passwords and fetching tokens to
actually drive those authentication
workflows you think about an agent it
doesn't really make sense for an agent
to log into a browser and log into a
workspace and get a token and do its
work sure it can do that like the
technology makes it possible but it's
very inefficient and so you think about
things like that and you realize there's
actually tons of scope for disruption
and tons of scope for new technology to
be built and so as an API company where
we are positioned is that we really work
closely with our customers to build out
the APIs today how those APIs get built
is going to evolve and I think the role
we will play is continue to kind of
build the picks and shovels the kind of
components the tool chains that they
will need to interact with agents to
build agents to let agents build APIs
themselves all that is really we are at
kind of day zero there's no framework
stacks there's no protocols there's no
kind of years of worth of standards that
have been built like we have today so
there's I think all of that is really up
for redefinition going forward so I
think yeah the agent side of things is
very exciting and I would actually say
like we're truly at day zero everything
we've seen is P or demo it's not
enterprise ready and it's a very far far
from being so so lots of opportunity for
companies like ours to go build the
right tools for enterprises to leverage
these things what's one piece of advice
that you would give an individual
contributor working in an organization
today thinking about where they want to
go with their career i think it's worth
thinking through kind of your
motivations and what is it that drives
you every day is it building the
technology is it building a business is
it team growth and the kind of people
aspect of it i think once you're able to
kind of hone in on what is the
motivating factor for you you can best
align yourself with the different roles
out there i think if you're an IC and
you really care about building amazing
technology and doing things like
defining standards and defining new
frameworks then you know growth as an IC
is immense it's maybe arguably the most
deep of all the tracks right there's
kind of an infinite amount that you
should learn and become an expert on i
think there's kind of the engineing
manager track where what you really care
about is efficiency productivity you
know building high performance teams
like really bringing together a group of
people who want to work with each other
and like do an amazing job and then
finally you know there's kind of if
you're motivated by business and trying
to think about that kind of fabled
product market fit then taking a leap as
a founder and doing that is a path to go
so I'm only describing three paths
probably a lot more but I think yeah
starting with those motivations of what
drives you and I think as an IC as a
individual contributor it takes some
time to figure that out because the kind
of day in day out of doing contributing
doesn't necessarily leave a ton of time
to think about this and get exposure so
I would say even before taking that leap
of faith trying to get a little bit of
exposure to all of these different paths
is great and one of the best ways to do
that and of course I'm biased is to work
at an early stage startup that is going
through that growth journey and there's
an immense amount of opportunity on all
those fronts technical contribution
management hiring you know selling
revenue and if you're able to do that
then I think as an individual
contributor you'll have the right
experiences to make an informed decision
so thanks very much a lot of interesting
ideas and good advice there if people
want to continue the conversation where
do they find so you can find me on
LinkedIn you can find me on X company
has a website through which you can
access a Slack community where we have
all of our customers and users we hang
out quite often so yeah I'm in all these
places and I'm based here in San
Francisco thanks so much for taking the
time to talk to us today thank you so
much Shane it's been a pleasure to be on
this podcast
[Music]

[Applause]
